question: ... last few years have brought many advances in the interests of women in naval service, particularly in the land-based maritime specialties. What's more, the Navy has instituted special sensitivity courses with an eye on --
answer: Whoa, whoa, whoa. "Land-based maritime specialties." Gimme a second here to de-euphemize that... Would that be anything like "typing"? "Restocking the cupboards"? That sort of thing, Mr. Hayes?

question: Hardly the case, Senator.
answer: Well, I'm just an old dame without much time left, so you'll pardon me if I jump right in here before they discontinue my blood-type. I am deeply concerned over the Navy's seemingly incontrovertible attitude toward women in the military. Case in point... "The Lark Report."

question: Madam Senator... this is an internal document of the U.S. Navy. I must seriously question whether --
answer: The Navy's conclusion regarding the crash of an F-14 aboard an aircraft carrier. Female aviator, it just so happens. You're familiar with this report and its conclusion, am I right?

question: I was one member of the investigating commission.
answer: Yes, I see your signature right here -- twice the size of everyone else's. And your conclusion was "pilot error," hmm?

question: I'm really not prepared for any kind of in-depth review of --
answer: I'd like to think our next Secretary of the Navy would be prepared for anything, Mr. Hayes.

question: The commission concluded that the aviator in question failed to execute a proper approach to the carrier.
answer: That aside for the moment, I'm struck by the tenor, the ill-spirit of your report... the degrading remarks by other aviators... innuendo about her performance in unrelated situations... even a reference to her sexual activity the weekend prior. In my seven years on this committee, I've never seen a downed aviator treated like this. Never. I'm deeply disturbed by this report, Mr. Hayes. Not just what it bodes for women in the military -- but for your own confirmation as well. ... a full 35 percent of all jobs in the U.S. military are still, to this day, off-limits to women. And that's simply gotta change. Sure. And we're gonna hog the bathroom, too.

question: I'll act surprised. 'Zat it? Ten minutes, nothin' on the table? Sweetcakes, you best go back to the President and tell him to open up the phone book and start lookin' for his next nominee.
answer: Administration's plan for 100 percent integration. If female candidates measure up in a series of test cases, the President will support full integration within three years' time. It's your gender-blind Navy, Senator. Surely you're not going to balk now.

question: Well, it's just that askin' you all to integrate the Navy is like sending a man to do a woman's job. How do you propose to handle the Combat Exclusion Laws?
answer: Keep narrowing the definitions. Keep redefining.

question: By calling women "Honorary Men." Ingenious.
answer: C'mon, Senator, President's pitchin' right down the center of your plate. If women measure up to men, they've got the job. You going to take a swing? Or step out of the box?

question: Lieutenant O'Neil.
answer: Gotta situation here. Where are you? Stuck in traffic?

question: Not due in for 22 minutes, sir. Watcha got?
answer: All right, stand by, we're going to switch over to COMSAT... Okay, fresh stuff

question: Do we know it's him using the beacon? Not a decoy?
answer: Signals received only sparingly, in such a pattern that leads us to conclude it is a downed aviator trying to conserve his batteries.

question: Chances of recovery?
answer: You're the analyst for East China, O'Neil. Analyze.

question: North Korean beaches are the best protected, most heavily monitored in the world. The civilian population is so propagandized that it acts as an Early Warning system. Extraction team has to be small and silent -- I'd go with Seals over Delta Force. Problem is, don't want to hold a conventional sub off-shore for target practice. Where's The Polk?
answer: Halfway 'round the world. So that's the problem -- we can get the team in, just not out.

question: Unless you Whiskey Run.
answer: Blank faces here, O'Neil.

question: Quick-hit technique used by Capone. Rigged a getaway car with running boards and handles. All his guys had to do was jump on and take a ride. Check the files -- DPRK-57 -- I doped it out as a contingency plan
answer: You expect the extraction team to ride the sub bare-back? Is that correct, O'Neil?

question: Only four minutes to neutral waters, sir. Why not?
answer: All right, sending the recommendation across the river. Royce out.

question: No, thank you, sir.
answer: That was good headwork, lieutenant.

question: Thank you, sir. We hear back from the Pentagon?
answer: Probably hear back from CNN first.

question: Hate this part. Just sweating it out on the sidelines.
answer: Intel has its own glory, lieutenant -- no matter how subtle. By the way, I'll need that option paper by 11-hundred today so I can review it with Admiral Hanover. And do we have any of that breakfast tea around here?

question: Is this my glory, sir?
answer: Jesus God, what now?

question: So everyone I talk to says you're top drawer with silk stockings inside.
answer: Thank you, ma'am. Um, may I ask what this is regarding?

question: High-school pentathlete... ROTC scholarship, graduated with honors... top marks in Basic Training... and, as it just so happens, a constituent of my home state of Virginia. Oh, the things I'll do for one extra vote. Lieutenant O'Neil, I am prepared to nominate you for the Navy's Special Reconnaissance program. Should you accept, you'll ship out to Coronado next week and join in the big testosterone festival. Complete the course, and you'll have a fast ticket to any assignment you want. That's my personal promise to you.
answer: "Coronado."

question: California.
answer: I know that, sir. Ma'am. It's just that... Beggin' your pardon, Senator, but... do you understand that this involves combat training?

question: This is just a test case, O'Neil. But if it works out -- if you work out -- it could well change the Navy's official policy on women in combat. Or, actually, its official non-policy. Now who's your immediate superior there?
answer: Captain Dwyer. Technically.

question: My office will fill him in and help expedite. Look forward to meeting you at the proper time. Jumping off now...
answer: Uh, question, ma'am.

question: Yes, dear.
answer: Would I be the only one? The only woman?

question: There'll be more to follow -- but yes, dear, right now you're the pick of a very large litter. And your success would mean a lot. Jumping, now...
answer: Well, shit-a-doodle-do... ... well, I survived Basic Training and three brothers -- so I know how to fight. What scares me are the sexual politics. I don't want to be turned into some poster girl for women's rights.

question: Well, shit-a-doodle-do... ... well, I survived Basic Training and three brothers -- so I know how to fight. What scares me are the sexual politics. I don't want to be turned into some poster girl for women's rights.
answer: So why're you even considering it? Are you?

question: Just like you would be.
answer: Spec-Recon. Those guys are world- class warriors. And they will not want you there, Jordan.

question: I take it you don't either. Feet.
answer: Well, you're doin' shit-hot at Intel.

question: Royce. We're the same age, we started the same time -- and now you're sitting in the upperdecks while I'm still down in the bullpen. What does that tell you about the Navy?
answer: She's haze grey and underway...

question: You need operational duty to really advance... you need combat training to go operational... yet combat training is off-limits to people with tits. I'm topped out at Intel. Forget the glass ceiling -- I'm beating my head on a big brass ceiling.
answer: So dump on me.

question: This has nothing to do with you.
answer: Well, guess I don't even need to be here...

question: Get your dick back here. It has everything to do with you.
answer: You're such a ball-breaker sometimes. Especially at night.

question: Sorry. But after our days... So if I try this thing... if I ship out to Coronado... what happens here?
answer: I'll try to keep the door open. If you wash out, I make it so that --

question: Wai', wait. What happens if it works? Four months of training, three years of operational duty. What then?
answer: I don't feel like doing an option paper on the rest of my life, Jordan. Maybe we should just let it happen.

question: Which is guy-speak for...
answer: Sounded lame as soon as it came out of my mouth. But I'm trying to be honest, okay? Three years is a long time. Don't ask me to predict how I'll feel then, Jordan, because I don't know. And either do you.

question: You know, right up until you said that -- I thought I did know.
answer: Jordan...

question: Go regulation if you can't do the reverses, O'Neil.
answer: Thank you, sir. But I like these just fine.

question: Not doin' them very fine, O'Neil.
answer: I'll try anyway, sir.

question: They're more afraid of you.
answer: Well, now I feel so much better.

question: It was made clear before you came -- harassment equals career suicide. Can't say anything good, so they don't say much at all. To your face, anyway.
answer: Whose orders were those?

question: It was made clear. Anyway, stay ballsy. First week's hell, then it levels out. Until S.E.R.E. training, anyway. That's hell-and-a-half.
answer: And how do you know that?

question: Made it to Week 10 last time.
answer: I didn't know they let you try again. Especially at your age.

question: Well, who the shit you think you are? Comin' in here like that?
answer: Your new roommate. Anybody usin' these drawers here?

question: Hey, hey, HEY. No possibility. You can't stay in here. You can't sleep right next to me.
answer: Funny, the C.O. says I can.

question: Aw, lookit this, lookit this -- she's bringin' Tampax in here. C'mon, you got nothin' but rooms over there.
answer: That your desk? I'll take this one.

question: WOULD YOU JUST GET OUTTA HERE?
answer: Listen, Sex Ape. I'm here to stay. And if you don't want me for a roommate or classmate, you got two options -- move out or ring out. End of file. What about you, McCool? Any problem with the room assignment?

question: Just do it, okay?
answer: If you can't feel the other guy's pecker, you ain't in tight enough! I want nuts to butts!

question: Come on, Montgomery...
answer: Flea! O'Neil! Why is there a break in that line?

question: Montgomery, why do they call you "Flea"?
answer: It's really "F. Lee Montgomery" -- but that gets whittled down to just "Flea." For short, ma'am.

question: So it really has nothing to do with actual brain size?
answer: No, ma'am.

question: Well, Flea, I appreciate the respect you just showed me. But I don't need it and don't want it -- not that kind of respect, anyway. It's just gonna hurt us both, okay?
answer: I'll work on it, ma'am.

question: Commander, are you of the habit of letting photographers traipse around your base snappin' their fill? These were supposed to have been discreet test cases -- -- and now I got reporters from Toadsquat, Iowa, calling my office and askin' what I know about this "G.I. Jane" thing. Are you truly mouthin' off to a senior member of the Senate Arms Committee? I mean, I'll give you points for style -- just nothin' for smarts.
answer: See me, sir?

question: Well, seein's how this thing is out, you let me handle the r.p.m. From this point forward, I want all press matters coordinated via my office. I'll be god-damned if I'm gonna watch Hayes pull flowers out of his ass and take credit for this one. Him or the President. This my shade? "Midnight Mahogany"? 'Cuz I'm comin' dangerously close to lookin' like Ronald Reagan here. Awright. How's our girl doin', anyway? Jordan, dear. How are they treating you?
answer: Can't complain, ma'am.

question: Hmmm. Maybe I'll ask when I see you in person.
answer: Uh, ma'am.

question: Gonna be visiting that all-woman's America's cup team in a few weeks -- If I were a gambler, I'd say Dennis O'Conner's days are numbered. But they're in San Diego, so I thought I'd take a quick promenade of the base. "Security"? What the hell you talkin' about? Your base isn't secure? Then set out the good plates, we'll all have lunch. My office will follow up with details. Jumping off, now...
answer: Sir, I want you to know that I had nothing to do with any of this. Not this article, not --

question: Next recovery! Keep goin', keep goin'! You know, the Israelis... ... they tried women in the 1967 War. Female soldiers.
answer: Permission to get dressed, sir?

question: It seems the men couldn't get used to the sight of women blown open and their viscera hanging from tree limbs. Israeli men would linger over wounded females -- often to the detriment of the mission, often endangering their own lives. They don't use women anymore.
answer: Sir, someone mentioned you received the Navy Cross. May I ask what you got it for?

question: For pulling a 210-pound man out of a burning barrack in Saudi Arabia.
answer: I see. So when a man tries to rescue another man, he's a hero. But when he tries to rescue a woman, he's gone soft.

question: Could you have pulled that 210-pound man clear, lieutenant? Females in combat situations impact unit cohesion. Men fight better without women around. And that is an historical fact.
answer: It also seems like a problem with the men's attitude, sir. So maybe you should be sniffing around their shower room instead.

question: England went out with a stress fracture. That puts you in charge, lieutenant.
answer: McCool's that same rank. We're both j.g.'s.

question: S.E.R.E. training coming up. They take you away to San Clemente Island. Half the guys quit when they come back. Supposed to be just hell-and-a-half.
answer: That's what I hear.

question: Can I ask you somethin', lieutenant? How come you're doing this? I mean, we're kinda curious.
answer: Who's "we"?

question: Just some of the women.
answer: I don't know if there's any single reason. But my father was Navy. And he had this old-time recruiting poster in his den. It showed a girl trying on a sailor's uniform while saying, "Gee, I wish I were a man! I'd join the Navy!" Was maybe 10 years old when I first saw it, and even then it felt wrong. Made me mad. And I don't think a month has gone by that I haven't thought about that poster. "Gee, I wish I were a man."

question: I've been accused of that wish.
answer: The woman I saw you with...

question: Just a friend. We have friends, too, you know.
answer: But are there... I mean, how many...

question: More than you'd guess. It's just that we don't hold coffee klatches. If more then three of us get together at any one time, the guys think it's some kind of uprising. Sounds funny now, but it's really not. We have to be careful. The Navy still knows how to put on a witch-hunt.
answer: Royce...

question: Royce...
answer: I've been trying you for five days. Don't they give you messages?

question: It's hard to find time to sleep, Royce. Much less keep up with my phone life.
answer: How hard they making it on you? That bad?

question: I feel like there's men here, there's women here -- then there's men. But hey, what'd I expect?
answer: Well, not this. I was doing the Pentagon scene few nights ago. Got some fresh stuff -- about you. You may be in a hostile camp. I think someone may be taking steps to ensure that you crash and burn.

question: Me? Why me?
answer: Don't you know? How they're talking about you?

question: I saw an article...
answer: I can't walk two blocks in Washington without hearing about "G.I. Jane." You're all over the place, and whether you wanted it or not, the feminists are sizing you up for that poster.

question: So why are you telling me this?
answer: Big symbols make big targets, Jordan. I think someone's gunning for you.

question: You know, Royce, I got enough heat on me without you turning up the jets, too.
answer: I'm only trying to warn you in case --

question: Well, let me warm you
answer: That's not what I want, Jordan. I mean... it is and it isn't...

question: Still can't make up your mind, huh? Gotta go, Royce.
answer: Jordan. You watch your ass.

question: Shit. Think we're had.
answer: Smoke her.

question: I ain't gonna shoot her.
answer: Only blanks. Lemme do it.

question: How long? Please, HOW LONG? "Don't know how much I can take"... "A little taste of death"... "Save the nail"... "It's been three days now"... Who is it?
answer: You know, I had an apartment about this size once.

question: Wick. They got your crew, too?
answer: Intagliata was out chasing breakfast. They found his tracks. Well, shit.

question: You really came back for more? Of this?
answer: When I was sittin' behind a desk in Washington, it made sense, somehow. Blame it on my big brother. He was Spec-Recon. And the stories he used to tell...

question: If you got a good one, Wick...
answer: One time he was doing a rekkie of the Libyan coastline. This is, like, right before we bombed Khadaffi into the past tense. So his crew does a nighttime infil, maps all the big artillery placements and stuff, then turns around to get the hell gone. But between them and the water are five Libyan guards, all armed to the nuts.

question: They had to kill 'em?
answer: Nah, they were dead-ass asleep. But on every guard's chest,they left one Marlboro cigarette. Just a little calling card to say they'd been there -- and could come back any time they wanted.

question: That's a good story.
answer: So the shit you gotta go through? To get from here to there? Brother said it was worth it. Worth the training... worth the divorce... worth anything.

question: He was married?
answer: At first.

question: You got anybody, Wick?
answer: Not me. You? O'Neil?

question: How'd you make it last time, Wick? How'd you get through this part?
answer: Last time I didn't.

question: Suitable for framing... Got time for a brain-pick?
answer: Subject?

question: O'Neil, Jordan.
answer: Thought you two were file-closed.

question: You knew about us?
answer: Sorry. Thought you knew I knew.

question: Computer -- no transcription, no com-link, no data-link. In fact... shut-down sequence 0-Niner-0-8, mark.
answer: All right. So who stands to gain if Jordan flames out in a big way?

question: The E-Ringers? Full integration is gonna cost the services billions at the worst possible time -- when Congress is already swinging the axe.
answer: Congress cuts, military bleeds. But Pentagon's a big place. Let's narrow the sights.

question: The Navy? They've made it clear they don't want to pull missiles out of subs to make room for women's heads. What's it gonna cost to make a fleet of Trident's co-ed?
answer: Sabotage born of economics? Wouldn't be a first. But is Hayes really going to start his watch with such a public failure?

question: Possibly. Just to spite DeHaven.
answer: Hmm. Let's aim higher. The White House. If Jordan wins, DeHaven wins in spades. Why? Well, it's been said that the only man the President fears -- ain't no man.

question: The first female President?
answer: Don't for a second think she didn't leak this story. "G.I. Jane" gives DeHaven a symbol that taps into the biggest constituency of them all.

question: Women.
answer: If you were the President, wouldn't that put a little piss in your shoes?

question: I don't know. Seems...
answer: This ain't about some little soldier girl sloggin' her way through commando school. The implications go way beyond.

question: Christ, I don't want to see her take a fall. She thinks I do, but...
answer: I take it this file is still open.

question: Even tough I don't talk to her every day -- I still talk to her every day. Know what I mean?
answer: Okay, so now work it from the other end. Think about California -- and how things might be handled there.

question: I don't... What, someone on base? A "mole"?
answer: This is what you get for brain- picking an old CIA spook. but if I needed to control the outcome of this test case, that's how I'd do it. A man-in-place. Makes everything very controllable.

question: What is your father's name? Simple question, lieutenant. No reason not to answer. What is your father's name?
answer: "Dad."

question: Any brothers? Sisters?
answer: Dick, Jane, and Spot.

question: Are you hungry? What's your favorite food? We'll try to get it for you.
answer: Green Eggs and Ham. You're not going to get anywhere. You might as well put me in the cage.

question: You are in the cage, O'Neil. Right here, right now.
answer: Should I be afraid?

question: Right down to your worthless womb, and I'll tell you why. This is my island. My world. And here I can get away with shit that would get me arrested anywhere else in the world. Take another scan of my little joy- boy outside. If I can do that to a Navy Seal, what's gonna happen to you? Huh? Why didn't you shoot the woman, O'Neil?
answer: Wasn't deemed a threat.

question: She led us right to you. That's no threat? Would you have shot if it was a man?
answer: No. Yes. I mean, depends on --

question: The others already told me, O'Neil. They wanted to shoot, but you wouldn't let them. Because you went soft on another women --
answer: That's not right.

question: That's what your crew said. Are they lying? Or are you?
answer: I think you're the liar.

question: I'm not the one who got five good men thrown in a bamboo cage. You wear the bars, you made the call, and you got your whole crew --
answer: We didn't know we were compromised. Firing would only've given away our position.

question: You think we should go easy on women, O'Neil? Do you?
answer: No.

question: I'm so glad we agree. Didn't you know you'd be raped if you were captured? Didn't you even think about that?
answer: Sure. Just like your men do.

question: I think we oughtta practice it, just so you know what to expect.
answer: Should I practice bleeding, too, sir? Would that make me a better soldier?

question: Three crews are still on this island somewhere. Who knows where?
answer: Don't do it, don't do it...

question: Who's gonna tell me? Who's gonna be chivalrous and stop this abuse? What, you want to see her get mauled? Is that it?
answer: Don't tell him shi --

question: You don't think she'd be raped if she were captured? You don't think the threat of rape would be used to leverage the men?
answer: You broke a dozen training rules back there -- before I lost count.

question: I've had it. Just because they pay me like a baby-sitter doesn't mean I'm gonna be one.
answer: She's a trainee, just like the others. Why are you coming down so hard?

question: She's an officer. There's a higher standard.
answer: She's a women, and that's why you're ridin' her bareback.

question: Of course it is. And I'm gonna stay on her until everyone realizes this is not some bullshit equal-rights thing, that real lives are gonna be lost. Maybe mine, maybe yours.
answer: I oughtta report you.

question: Sorry, didn't mean to --
answer: That's okay. Just an ex-girlfriend. And know I remember why.

question: First big night of liberty and no date? You're pathetic, Wickwire.
answer: Maybe I'll just head over to McP's with the others, have a drink or four. Don't wanna come, do you?

question: I can't go out. Not like this.
answer: I think you look beautiful.

question: See me, sir? Sir, if someone is suggesting that I'm a lesbian, they're wrong. They're very wrong. And I'd like to know where you got this information.
answer: I'm sorry, O'Neil. But as class officer, it's my obligation to report all violations.

question: This is insane. You've got no proof. We hugged. Because the men didn't want me eating with them. Jesus Christ, let's get this right.
answer: I wish I didn't have to do this, Jordan.

question: I want to kill them... I want to kill the guys who made you cry like this...
answer: All I wanted was an honest chance. And If I couldn't get it, I couldn't stay.

question: And this class officer... "Wickwire." You think he was just trying to get even? Striking back for...
answer: Maybe. Though it didn't seem like he was getting any satisfaction out of it. Almost like... Did I say he was class officer?

question: Almost like someone put him up to it. Okay, who?
answer: No shortage of suspects.

question: The Chief? Or maybe even Turrentine? Your C.O.?
answer: Royce. Tell me you didn't keep a file on me.

question: Somebody was yankin' your stings, Jordan -- maybe from 3,000 miles away. I wanted to know who. I still do. C'mon, Jordan. Do the headwork with me.
answer: It's done with, Royce. Let it go.

question: Someone screwed you over like this, left unanswered charges hanging over your head, and you're not gonna fight back?
answer: I'm tired of fighting back. I just wanted to come home and be safe and have you here and the river there and just forget the rest of the world, okay?

question: Well, before you crawl off to die, Jordan, give me five minutes of good headwork. "John James Urgayle." The Chief.
answer: What about him. Instructors typically pull three year assignments. This guy's in and out in one year -- your year. That sound right? Sounds like an amazing coincidence.

question: Or like maybe he was baby sitting a problem child for the Navy.
answer: I don't know, I don't care.

question: "In Washington..."
answer: What?

question: Wickwire said he was dry-docked in Washington between stints at Coronado...
answer: "Wickwire, Thomas Dane"... Second run at Coronado... and correct, they had him stashed in the "Appropriation Liaison Office," whatever that is.

question: You don't crap out of Spec-Recon and get another shot without dispensation from someone up in flag country. He's got a Sea Daddy somewhere.
answer: I'd sure like to know who.

question: Yeah. Me too.
answer: Administration, Ensign Blondell.

question: Don't say my name.
answer: Who's... Lieuten --

question: Or rank. But can you do me a favor and pull a transfer order?
answer: Okay, but... You didn't have to do what you did. Not for me.

question: "Wickwire, Thomas Dane." See what you can find.
answer: Got it.

question: Who signed as his "sponsoring officer"?
answer: Uh... don't see it. There's no signature. But hang on -- there's a note to "See Addendum." Checking... Wow...

question: Lieutenant j.g. O'Neil.
answer: Ms. O'Neil. Yes, of course. I'm Douglas Champeau. Unfortunately, the Senator is in chamber right now. How can I help you?

question: What chamber? Which way is that?
answer: I mean, she's on the floor of the Senate.

question: Okay, which way?
answer: She really can't be disturbed. But if you care to wait, I'll find you an office with a phone. It might be several hours, but -- See the secretary, please.

question: Senator DeHaven... DeHaven... We can talk here or we can talk outside, Senator. You tell me.
answer: Cloak room. I'll meet her there. Just her. Jordan. I always hoped we'd get together -- though just now I'm gearing up for a child-care vote that --

question: Lieutenant Thomas Wickwire. You know him.
answer: Sounds familiar.

question: It should. You nominated him for Spec-Recon just three days after you nominated me.
answer: Jordan. Might we do this over lunch tomorrow? I do very much want to talk, but now is scarcely --

question: Did you set me up? Did you set me up just to see me fail?
answer: Absolutely not. Wickwire was there to help. To be my eyes on the inside, to make sure you were getting a fair shot. At least that was the intent.

question: What changed?
answer: Should probably ask him that.

question: If I have to ask again, Senator, I'll be asking in front of cameras.
answer: Two seconds, Walter. In 1981, the Supreme Court was asked to rule on the issue of women in combat positions. The Court cited the 1948 Combat Exclusion Laws as a legal foundation for keeping women ineligible. That decision held for all these years -- until the White House, 10 days ago, moved to have the Exclusion Laws voided. To demolish that legal foundation.

question: So? Isn't the President jumping on your bandwagon?
answer: What he did was light the bandwagon on fire. Because he knows what I know -- that American families are not prepared to put their daughters in harm's way.

question: You don't know that.
answer: In face, I do

question: What are you saying? That a women's life is more valuable than a man's? That a women's death hurts a family more?
answer: I'm saying it's not going to happen. Not when the President is set to turn this into a third-rail issue should I choose to ever campaign against him. He will fry me six ways to Sunday for sending daughters and young mothers off to war -- and, quite possibly, for bringing them back in body bags.

question: You were never going to let women serve in combat. You always had a safety net. Or thought you did.
answer: Jordan. I don't expect you to fully understand this -- but sometimes there's more to be gained from the fight than the victory.

question: So the rhetoric gets you headlines. But the reality gets you in trouble.
answer: The reality is this

question: I wanted the choice. The chance to prove myself, my skills, my work, me. That's how it should've been.
answer: Just hold the goddamn clock, Walter. I once promised you a fast ticket, Jordan, and I always meant to make good on that. Come work for me. I can always use a hard-charger on my team.

question: You promise Wickwire a fast ticket, too?
answer: I've had no direct communication with him since this whole thing began. And that's quite verifiable.

question: I'm sure it is.
answer: You'll think about my offer?

question: You know, I wonder what the SecNav would think about it. If I spoke with him.
answer: Well, I spoke with Mr. Hayes this morning myself -- and told him the deal was off. No more test cases. He was only too happy to oblige. Don't play politics with me, little darlin'. You'd be up way past your bedtime. I'll call you in a few days.

question: Lieutenant? I was asked to give you this.
answer: The Navy Cross...

question: I believe he earned it for saving a man's life in Saudi Arabia. He wanted you to have it. He was very clear on that point.
answer: I was looking for him earlier, but...

question: The Chief was granted early retirement as of 17-hundred yesterday. By 18-hundred he was gone. Out of the Navy.
answer: Just a coincidence?
